'''''The History of The Hobbit''''' traces the evolution of [[J.R.R. Tolkien]]'s ''[[The Hobbit]]'' through the various extant manuscripts and drafts (formerly unpublished). The editor
column3: presents an extensive study on the early development of ''The Hobbit''
column4: and also details how Tolkien made revisions to the story to accommodate the events in ''[[The Lord of the Rings]]''.

column1: [[File:Return to Bag End.jpg|thumb|left|Cover of Part Two
The first edition of ''The History of'' The Hobbit was released in two parts
column2: '''''Mr. Baggins''''' (Part One) and '''''Return to Bag End''''' (Part Two) in May and June of 2007 in the U.K. by HarperCollins
column3: then in September in the U.S. by Houghton Mifflin
column4: which also released it as a boxed set in October. The [http://www.houghtonmifflinbooks.com/catalog/titledetail.cfm?titleNumber=1022629 Houghton Mifflin boxed set] also includes a new edition of ''[[The Hobbit]]'' with a short introduction by [[Christopher Tolkien]]
column5: a reset text incorporating the most up-to-date corrections
column6: and all of Tolkien's own drawings and color illustrations
column7: including the rare "Mirkwood" piece.<ref>[http://www.houghtonmifflinbooks.com/catalog/titledetail.cfm?titleNumber=1022629 The History of the Hobbit Book Information] at [http://www.hmhbooks.com/ Houghton Mifflin Harcourt] (accessed 18 April 2011)</ref>

column1: In an interview conducted before the publication
column2: Rateliff described the undertaking in the following way:
which I've been working on for years and will finally be sending to the publisher near the end of this year
column3: is a book called The History of The Hobbit. It's rather along the lines of Christopher Tolkien's editions that make up the History of Middle-Earth series (which I highly recommend if you haven't read them): an edition of the original manuscript of The Hobbit with extensive commentary on how Mr. Baggins' story fits into Tolkien's legendarium. It's a big book filled with the entire text of Tolkien's first draft
column4: along with short essays about everything from rings of invisibility or Tolkien's spiders to a detailed account of just when Tolkien wrote the book (which can actually be reconstructed from available evidence to within a month or two on either end). I hope people will like it when it finally sees the light of day.|[[John Rateliff]]<ref>[http://www.montecook.com/cgi-bin/page.cgi?int_dnd30_Rateliff A Talk With John D. Rateliff] at [http://www.montecook.com/cgi-bin/page.cgi?montejournal Monte's Journal] (accessed 18 April 2011)</ref>}}

In one volume for the first time
column2: this revised and updated examination of how J.R.R.Tolkien came to write his original masterpiece ''The Hobbit'' includes his complete unpublished draft version of the story
column3: together with notes and illustrations by Tolkien himself.

column1: For the first time in one volume
column2: ''The History of'' The Hobbit presents the complete unpublished text of the original manuscript of J.R.R. Tolkien's ''The Hobbit''
column3: accompanied by John Rateliff's lively and informative account of how the book came to be written and published. As well as recording the numerous changes made to the story both before and after publication
column4: it examines – chapter-by-chapter – why those changes were made and how they reflect Tolkien's ever-growing concept of Middle-earth.

column1: ''The Hobbit'' was first published on 21 September 1937. Like its successor
column3: it is a story that "grew in the telling"
column4: and many characters and story threads in the published text are completely different from what Tolkien first wrote to read aloud to his young sons as part of their "fireside reads".

column1: As well as reproducing the original version of one of literature's most famous stories
column2: both on its own merits and as the foundation for ''The Lord of the Rings''
column3: this new book includes many little-known illustrations and previously unpublished maps for ''The Hobbit'' by Tolkien himself. Also featured are extensive annotations and commentaries on the date of composition
column4: how Tolkien's professional and early mythological writings influenced the story
column6: and how Tolkien came to revise the book years after publication to accommodate events in ''The Lord of the Rings''.

column1: Like Christopher Tolkien's ''The History of'' The Lord of the Rings before it
column2: this is a thoughtful yet exhaustive examination of one of the most treasured stories in English literature. Long overdue for a classic book now celebrating 75 years in print
column3: this companion edition offers fascinating new insights for those who have grown up with this enchanting tale
column4: and will delight those who are about to enter Bilbo's round door for the first time.

column1: John D. Rateliff moved to Wisconsin in 1981 in order to work with the Tolkien manuscripts at Marquette University. He has been active in Tolkien scholarship for many years
column2: delivering papers on Tolkien and the Inklings. While at Marquette
column3: he assisted in the collation of their holdings with those Christopher Tolkien was editing for his History of Middle-earth series. A professional editor
column4: he lives in the Seattle area with his wife and three cats
column5: only one of whom is named after a Tolkien character.
